title: Shock Treatment
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

sections.heading: 1. Lay the Person Down, if Possible
bullets: Elevate the person's feet about 12 inches unless head, neck, or back is injured or you suspect broken hip or leg bones.
Do not raise the person's head.
Turn the person on side if they are vomiting or bleeding from the mouth.

items: Elevate the person's feet about 12 inches unless head, neck, or back is injured or you suspect broken hip or leg bones.
Do not raise the person's head.
Turn the person on side if they are vomiting or bleeding from the mouth.

sections.heading: 2. Begin CPR, if Necessary
content: If the person is not breathing or breathing seems dangerously weak:
bullets: For a child, start CPR for children .
For an adult, start adult CPR .
Continue CPR until help arrives or the person wakes up.

content_blocks.text: If the person is not breathing or breathing seems dangerously weak:
associated_bullets: For a child, start CPR for children .
For an adult, start adult CPR .
Continue CPR until help arrives or the person wakes up.

sections.heading: 4. Keep Person Warm and Comfortable
bullets: Loosen restrictive clothing.
Cover with a coat or blanket.
Keep the person still. Do not move the person unless there is danger.
Reassure the person.
Do not give anything to eat or drink.

items: Loosen restrictive clothing.
Cover with a coat or blanket.
Keep the person still. Do not move the person unless there is danger.
Reassure the person.
Do not give anything to eat or drink.

sections.heading: 5. Follow Up
content: Blood test, urine tests, heart test and x-rays and/or CT scans may be done.
bullets: At the hospital, the person will be given oxygen and intravenous fluids.
Other treatment will depend on the cause of shock.

items: At the hospital, the person will be given oxygen and intravenous fluids.
